Award.AwardTitle: Reconciling Local Livelihoods with Global Production Networks in Yucatan, Mexico

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The transformation of agrifood production and distribution networks has emerged as an issue of global importance in recent years as both scholars and policymakers have sought strategies to promote the integration of small-scale producers in global commodity chains. In order to conceptualize the structure and governance of global agrifood networks, assess the related distribution of economic benefits, and offer policy prescriptions for improving the livelihoods of small-scale producers, researchers and policymakers have employed two increasingly influential analytical frameworks: global value chain (GVC) analysis and the global production networks (GPN) framework. Notwithstanding important differences, both GVC and GPN approaches conceptualize the benefits of participation in global production and distribution systems, and corresponding livelihood implications, solely in terms of the generation, enhancement (upgrading), and capture (distribution) of economic value. However, the vast majority of small-scale agricultural and livestock producers in the Global South are simultaneously embedded in alternative non-market systems of exchange and their livelihoods are not defined solely in terms of market capitalist relations. In failing to acknowledge the reality of rural livelihoods in the Global South, GVC and GPN frameworks present a singular vision of development, which privileges value and implicitly portrays small-scale producers as embryonic small capitalist enterprises. As a consequence, both GVC analysis and the GPN framework share a fundamental conceptual and theoretical flaw and policy prescriptions drawn from these approaches misdiagnose the failure of small-scale producers to benefit from integration with global networks and inadvertently exclude the majority of small-scale producers from the benefits of participation in global agrifood systems.

This project, focusing on the role of Japanese snack food producers, trading companies and consumers in transforming the production and distribution systems of chile habanero in Yucatán, Mexico and concomitant livelihood implications among small-scale producers, will contribute to the theoretical and empirical literature on GPNs in three important ways. On the one hand, by focusing on existing livelihood practices in Yucatán and the interface between alternative non-market systems of exchange and global production networks, rather than simply equating development and livelihoods with value and an idealized singular form of market capitalism, the project resolves a fundamental conceptual and theoretical flaw in the GPN framework. In addition, the case study of Japanese snack food producers and consumers addresses another perceived shortcoming of the GPN framework, its failure to conceptualize explicitly the agency of final consumers in transforming the structure and governance of global production networks. Furthermore, by revealing how policy frameworks which privilege the generation, enhancement and capture of economic value and which inadvertently marginalize small-scale producers, this project will contribute to improving rural livelihoods in Yucatán by promoting collaboration between habanero growers and other stakeholders. The project will also contribute to transforming the local policy arena in order to "make space" for small-scale producers within global agrifood networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this project is to gain a more complete understanding of how a complex network of stakeholders operating at global and local scales transform the production and distribution systems of chile habanero, a traditional horticultural product in Yucatán, Mexico (see attached figure), and concomitant livelihood implications among small-scale producers. The project also assesses the strengths, weaknesses and contradictions of two prevailing and widely accepted conceptual approaches for devising policies to improve livelihoods and promote regional development – the global value chains (GVC) and global production networks (GPN) frameworks.

With the assistance of a graduate research assistant and several collaborating undergraduate students, a combination of interviews, participant observation and secondary data were collected in both Mexico and Japan to analyze a host of actors and institutions, which have emerged during the past decade to regulate and govern the production and distribution of chile habanero in the study area. Of particular interest are the role of Japanese snack food producers in increasing demand for habanero peppers and dictating quality control standards, the creation of local institutions (such as a Habanero Regulatory Council modeled on the example of the tequila industry) to implement norms and regulate the industry, and, especially, the authorization of certified designation of origin (CDO) status for chile habanero cultivated in the Yucatán Peninsula.

From the perspective of GVC and GPN frameworks, the imposition of a new set of institutional relationships and the CDO designation, specifically, represent successful examples of upgrading and the enhancement of value creation, with purported benefits for a host of participants in chile habanero production and distribution systems. However, in practice, the project finds that the emerging governance context in Yucatán increases production costs and fails to deliver higher prices, ultimately resulting in the exclusion of small-scale producers from the potential benefits of increasing habanero production and integration with the global economy. In particular, CDO designation has led to increasingly large-scale, agro-industrial production based on greenhouses, improved seed and high levels of chemical inputs. Paradoxically, the primary demand for habanero has shifted to industrial uses and intermediate inputs, rather than fresh peppers or salsa. This new institutional context and its associated production and distribution regime reject indigenous traditions while using indigenous producers as window-dressing, leading to the systematic withdrawal of small-scale producers. In response to the exclusion of small-scale producers in the state of Yucatán, the extension of CDO status to the rest of the Yucatán Peninsula allows key intermediaries and large producers to gain access to land and labor needed in order to meet the demands of global markets.

From a conceptual standpoint, this study concludes that the imposition of a new regulatory setting does not solely promote integration with global markets, rather it redefines the social context within which habanero peppers are produced. In general, an institutional context informed by GVC and GPN approaches exacerbates disparities by attributing the exclusion of small-scale agricultural producers to a “deficit perspective” and their failure and inability to adapt to the purported universal model of market capitalism.
